ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Writing skills and insights about the aspects of a good piece of writing.
I learned how to write more vividly, how to read for structure, and general writing conventions. Improved ability to give and receive constructive criticism.

Writing powerful, persuasive essays that are drawn from various sources  personal experience, non-fiction articles, parody, etc. Also learned a great deal about how to revise your writing to make it more clear to the readers
Got to read some cool essays. Learned how to effectively respond to criticism (i.e. knowing what advice to take and what to stand by as an author)
very much improved writing and analyzing skills
I learned how to hone my non-fiction essay writing skills, and also how to use constructive feedback to improve my essays.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The discussion format really aids in keeping the class engaging. There is a lot of clear feedback given in your writing and, for the most part, the readings are pretty interesting. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes the deadlines are a bit rushed as we did have to write 4 longer essays and 1 short one.

Strengths: Prof Saraceni is really sweet and cares about all of her students; she checked in on everyone at the start of every class which was nice. She also has a ton of energy and even though our class was only at 11:35am, it helped lift my spirits a bit to keep going through the day. The essays in the personal essay, humor, and cultural criticism units were pretty good for the most part. Breakout rooms were fun and gave me a chance to bond (albeit virtually) with other members in the class. 

Weaknesses: Essays in the place and portrait units were painful to get through (not in an emotionally satisfying way though moreso just a boring omg this thing is like 15 pages long way). All we did in class was talk about the essays and not really practice how to improve our own writing? Like I felt like I was just kind of writing the essays blindly each unit. And I know I'm a strong writer so I didn't go in expecting this course to be ~life-changing~ or anything but I wish I was able to see a more tangible increase in my writing quality. I was really not pleased with the conditions for the place or portrait essays either. My displeasure was mainly a consequence of COVID, but whereas it was physically limiting with the place essay (there were very few places on campus that I was allowed to visit and even less so that I felt comfortable visiting for a long period of time), it was unreasonably binding for the portrait essay (we couldn't interview fellow yalies, romantic partners (which?? is not something I feel like many students would even consider??), or immediate family members and in the age of COVID, that meant basically everyone wrote about their grandparents or a childhood friend).

In the beginning of the course, we focused mainly on the beginnings of essays, but with midterm feedback we started assessing the entire essays holistically. The asynchronous meetups with other students were also helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussion format worked well and the breakout rooms were nice to bounce off ideas.

I liked the breakout rooms at the start of the class, and it was sad that we lost them because they were very effective in helping the class bond and exchange ideas. Changing up the class (in terms of structure) could've been helpful too because it was literally just log on, talk about essay 1, talk about essay 2, log off week after week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would! I think this is a great course to fulfill your writing credits. It is fun and engaging and it allows for plenty of creativity even though you are technically writing nonfiction. There is a lot of feedback given between your rough draft and final drafts and the workshops were great.
Would definitely recommend. It is an amazing course that will take your writing a step further, which will help you not only throughout college, but beyond.

Kinda. If you want a relatively chill writing class (chill in the sense that the class environment is chill, there's still a considerable amount of writing) and know you're already a strong writer, then yes, this is the class for you. If you don't want to do a lot of writing throughout the semester, this probably isn't the class for you.
Great class, Prof. Saraceni actually uses feedback from students. The class was a pleasure to take; if you want to take an engl 120 section, this one is great.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Short writing assignments typically written in class during the normal school year were assigned as outside of class assignments in addition to readings.
Some asynchronous assignments, like short meetings with other members of the class
